 I'll explain since I do have some education and experience in matters of vertebrate zoology and in ornithology.
 
 The last item on the list is gastralia. These are abdominal ribs composed of dermal bone. The exist in reptiles and fossil dinosaurs also had them, even theropod dinosaurs. Birds don't have gastralia - not a single known example of a living bird has gastralia (and I am not aware of a single reptile that lacks them in one form or another). Archaeopteryx had gastralia - they are quite obvious and one of the reasons why some specimens were classified as dinosaurs.
 
 If Archaeopteryx is just a bird, why does it have gastralia? The other characteristics mentioned are similar - birds and Archaeopteryx have them while reptiles and dinosaurs don't, others reptiles, dinosaurs and Archaeopteryx have, while birds don't. The problem is which is which and to explain it from the point of creationism. Why is a bird with dinosaur characteristics not a transitional?
Perhaps I'm nitpicking, but some advanced therapsids had no gastralia. I believe that there were some dinosaurs also lacking them.

Then I stand corrected. But as I said, "I am not aware of..." I pulled out my dictionary of biology and looked up "gastralia." Wasn't there. (How sad. Maybe I should trash it.)
 
 At any rate, gastralia are characteristic of diapsids (except turtles). They are found in the lepidosaurs (of which snakes and lizards are members) as well as the sauropods and theropods. Gastralia are derived from the archosaurs. They may be lost in some lineages (birds for example, or advanced therapsids as you point out [logical since mammals don't have gastralia], and maybe other dinosaurs).
 
 However, Archaeopteryx isn't a therapsid, it is a theropod, and it has gastralia, just like saruopods and theropods. Birds (none, not any) do not have gastralia - just like the therapsids don't have gastralia.
